awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2019:  Can community assembly theory explain assembly and reassembly in dryland ecosystems?
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2019, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. Understanding how natural communities are structured is a fundamental question in ecology, with important implications for conservation. According to ecological theory, the number of species, and abundance of each species in a community is affected by how species' traits, such as size and growth rate, interact with the environment. This project investigates how precipitation and biological soil crusts (biocrusts are communities of moss, lichen, cyanobacteria and other biota that cover soil surfaces among vascular plants in drylands) influence plant species growing in dryland communities. The research will test ecological theory to determine the factors that influence native and invasive species plant establishment in dryland ecosystems. Throughout this project, the fellow will partner with established programs, focused on increasing the representation of underrepresented groups in science, to train, mentor, and provide independent research experiences for students during the academic year and in summer programs.

Specifically, the proposed work will test the ability of using community assembly theory to explain the assembly of native plant communities and predict exotic plant invasions by conducting parallel field experiments in disparate drylands and quantifying relationships between plant traits at the seed and seedling stage and recruitment success while manipulating rainfall and biocrust filters. Understanding how rainfall patterns and biocrusts influence plant establishment will inform directed community reassembly for restoration purposes. Outreach activities include collaboration with the Doris Duke Conservation Scholars program to mentor a diverse cohort of students dedicated to conservation. The fellow will also pair with four existing programs at CU Boulder to provide one-on-one mentoring for undergraduate students from disadvantaged groups and develop research-based educational material for K-12 students to enhance the early exposure of pre-college students to environmental biology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The presence and relative abundance of individual plant species varies across locations. Community assembly theory suggests that these differences in plant community structure are influenced by how species traits interact with various filters in the environment, like temperature or soil moisture. It can be difficult to test this theory in practice because there are often multiple filters affecting the community at the same time. Recently, a new way of evaluating this theory was proposed that involves experimentally manipulating different filters and observing how the traits of different species affect their success in the community. By doing this, we can determine which filters are most important and how specific traits of species contribute to the overall structure of the community. This method can help us better understand how natural communities are put together and how we can protect them in the face of environmental challenges.

Dryland ecosystems cover over 40% of the land surface and are increasingly impacted by climate change and invasive plant species. Precipitation is a key filter in drylands that limits plant recruitment and growth. Biological soil crusts (biocrusts) are another important filter in these systems that regulate plant recruitment directly and through their interactions with precipitation. The early stages of germination and recruitment in dryland systems are challenging for most seedlings, resulting in the majority of them dying. Therefore, these filters that affect seedling survival may have a significant impact on how dryland communities are organized. The research aims to assess the effectiveness of community assembly theory in achieving the following objectives: 1) explaining the formation of native plant communities in dryland systems by studying trait interactions with crucial filters, 2) predicting the success of invasive plant species in the same systems, and 3) using trait-filter interactions of native plants to identify the best-suited species for restoration purposes in dryland ecosystems.

Intellectual Merit. The major research goal of this project was to generate an improved understanding of the interactive role that biocrusts and precipitation play in the development of dryland plant communities. We proposed to do this through the lens of community assembly theory. The majority of studies examining the relationship between plant traits and abundance have focused on adult plants, despite the fact that seedlings and adults possess distinct traits. Seedlings are also more sensitive to environmental conditions than adults, and transitions from seed to seedling and seedling to juvenile plant are critical stages that impact adult plant abundance and distribution. Here, we specifically focused on seedling functional traits and understanding how different traits and trait combinations may relate to native and invasive plant success in dryland plant communities.

Broader Impacts. Career development was a key aspect of our broader impacts. Extensive amounts of formal training and were provided to develop undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral skills in research, teaching, mentoring, leadership, and communication. We also pursued outreach and informal education opportunities by: (1) developing teaching modules for land managers and undergraduate students, (2) creating workshops on skills development for undergraduate students, and (3) serving on informational panels for students interested in careers in ecology.
